header.title: Satanic Theology: Exploring the Left-Hand Path

central_thesis: The article provides a structured analysis of Satanic and Setian philosophies, establishing their existential authenticity within the Left-Hand Path. It meticulously distinguishes LaVeyan Satanism (focused on Indulgence and psychodramatic atheism) from Setian philosophy (centered on Xeper, the concept of Set as a sentient being, and a dualistic, psyche-centric reality). The core argument advocates for Xeper (Becoming) as a perpetually evolving, self-driven process of individual actualization and mastery, crucial for avoiding spiritual stasis and achieving a divine state of being, contrasting this with Right-Hand Path traditions and reframing the concept of 'God' as impersonal 'natural law'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Satanic and Setian Philosophy
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the foundational tenets of LaVeyan Satanism (Indulgence, psychodramatic atheism) and Setian philosophy (Xeper, Set as patron), clarifying misconceptions and establishing their respective existential frameworks. It emphasizes the metaphorical interpretation of 'gods' and distinguishes between esoteric and exoteric understanding within ancient traditions.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Right-Hand vs. the Left-Hand Path
structure_content.summary: This part defines the Right-Hand Path as seeking ego dissolution and conformity, contrasting it with the Left-Hand Path's exaltation of individual will and self-awareness. It portrays the 'Devil' as a 'friend' for Setians and critiques Christian determinism while advocating for moral relativism and the importance of pride as a foundation for self-esteem and the ability to love others.

The Setian concept of 'God' is equated with 'natural law'—a non-conscious, mechanical existence. Anthropomorphic and personal notions of 'God' are rejected as illogical, inconsistent, and limiting. The article critiques theodicies attempting to reconcile 'God's' goodness with 'natural evil' and dismisses the notion of 'God' as a basis for ethics due to its impersonal and amoral nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: The 'Fall' of Man vs. his Rise
structure_content.summary: This section posits individual will as a non-natural phenomenon, alien to the material universe and its laws. It argues that the Left-Hand Path exalts this non-natural aspect of man, reinterpreting the Biblical 'Fall' myth not as a descent, but as a rise into self-awareness and freedom, a gift that produces pain but also strengthens consciousness.

The Setian perspective asserts that the concept of 'God' as an absolute standard is a human creation. It advocates for 'neo-polytheism,' where the individual Setian 'becomes a god' through self-validation and mastery over their 'subjective universe.' Reality is viewed as a relativistic, subjective construct, emphasizing a 'psyche-centric' consciousness (individual at the center, recognizing other subjective universes) over 'monotheocentric' views (God at the center). It aligns with 'master morality,' driven by life-affirming actions rather than fear of punishment.

The article champions critical doubt and inquiry over blind faith, which is considered an impediment to truth. While acknowledging that all philosophies rely on assumptions, it stresses that Setianism bases its 'faith' on careful consideration. It also introduces the 'Greater Black Magical working' as a means of intuitive knowing and apprehending essences, thereby expanding beyond purely logical positivism.

key_concepts.definition: A philosophy, as set forth by Anton LaVey, primarily based on 'Indulgence' – an emphasis on man's carnal aspect and freedom. It views 'Satan' as a metaphor for hedonism and free-spiritedness, often manifesting as psychodramatic atheism aimed at shedding irrational guilt and questioning conventional moralisms and the altruism of humanity.

An eclectic and existential philosophy that evolved from earlier Satanic thought, with 'Xeper' as its first principle. It posits Set as an actual, sentient being and a teacher, and views man's individual essence as separate from the physical universe, embodying a form of dualism. It is psyche-centric, emphasizing mastery by the individual over their subjective universe and self-validation towards a 'divine state of being'.

An Egyptian hieroglyph meaning 'become' or 'Come into Being,' symbolized by the scarab beetle. It is the first principle of Setian philosophy, representing an open-ended, perpetually unattainable goal. This constant process of 'Becoming' is considered the only effective measure against spiritual death, providing vitality and existential authenticity.

Philosophies and religions that exalt individual will and self-awareness as the highest value. Rather than seeking dissolution into a greater 'God,' practitioners aim to strengthen their individual essence. The 'Devil' is understood as a friend, symbolizing 'discord' or 'multiplicity,' which is valued over 'peace' (conformity/stasis).

Religions and philosophies that disparage the 'ego' or individual self, seeking conformity of thought and action, and ultimately advocating for the dissolution of individual essence into 'God.' They aim to destroy self-consciousness in pursuit of peace, which the Left-Hand Path critiques as a state of oblivion or inaction.

In Setian philosophy, the religious concept of 'God' is conceived as roughly equivalent to the scientific concept of 'natural law,' identified with the unity of non-conscious, mechanical existence. Anthropomorphic, personal, all-good notions are rejected as illogical. This 'God' is seen as remote, intangible, amoral, unapproachable, and undeserving of worship, thus not serving as a basis for ethics.

A non-natural phenomenon alien to the natural universe and thus not wholly subject to its laws. It is central to Satanic/Setian philosophy, representing the unique, self-aware aspect of man that distinguishes him from beasts. Its exaltation is seen as man's 'rise' or liberation, contrasting with traditional interpretations of the 'Fall' as a descent.

A Setian perspective that places the individual at the center of their own subjective universe. Reality is largely understood as a subjective construct, and the individual determines the value of all that exists therein through attribution. It recognizes the existence of other subjective universes, contrasting with 'monotheocentric' views that place 'God' at the center.

The first principle of LaVeyan Satanism, emphasizing the carnal aspect of man that has been repressed by conventional religions, leading to neuroses. As clarified in the notes, 'true Indulgence' – the exercise of free will – presupposes profound self-knowledge.

A ritual or ceremony described as an 'exploration of essence,' a process through which the higher self or spiritual being of the initiate is unmasked, and a knowledge of Set (the source of the being) is manifested. It involves the intuition of essences by means of 'free imaginative variation' to gain knowledge.

practical_system.description: The practical system derived from this philosophical exposition is one of radical individual self-actualization and self-creation, termed 'Becoming' (Xeper). It is not a rigid set of rituals but a continuous process of internal and external mastery. The core operative principle is for the individual to become a 'god in his own right' by assuming existential responsibility for self-validation and by actively shaping their 'subjective universe.' This involves developing a 'psyche-centric consciousness,' where the individual determines value and meaning, rather than relying on external, monotheocentric standards. The system encourages constant questioning, critical thought, and the rejection of blind faith in favor of direct experience and personal gnosis.
tools: Critical thinking and doubt (as opposed to blind faith)
Introspection and self-analysis (to develop self-knowledge and self-esteem)
Understanding and application of the 'individual will' (as a non-natural, creative force)
Attribution of value (to construct one's subjective reality)
The Crystal Tablet of Set (as a foundational text for I°s and II°s)
The Tarot (potentially as an 'LBM prop' for Black Adepts, used with understanding and self-direction, not for divination)
rituals: Psychodramas (in early LaVeyan Satanism, to shed guilt)
Greater Black Magical working (exploration of essence to unmask the higher self and manifest knowledge of Set, the source of being)

relevant_quotes.text: The Setian philosophy espoused by the Temple of Set is highly eclectic and existential. For this reason the sacred and mythical animals associated with the neters [often loosely translated as 'gods' but perhaps more accurately likened to to the Platonic Forms] are interpreted in a highly metaphorical and allegorical manner.

By Satanism I do not refer to the nefarious activities of juvenile delinquents and psychopaths. Such activities as human or animal sacrifice are looked upon with extreme disparagement by Satanists, Setians, and Thelemites.

Therefore the only effective measure against spiritual death, which results from the feelings or emptiness that afflict such a large percentage of the world's population and which is often the cause of physical death4, is a goal or ideal which is never fully attainable. Such a goal is Becoming.5

As time progressed, the Satanic philosophy was to take two quite distinctive directions, the first being a form of psychodramatic atheism in which 'Satan' was seen as merely an allegory for the carnal aspect of man and hedonistic self-indulgence, the second viewing Satan as an actual, sentient being separate from the physical universe, and the very source of man's being and his capacity for non-natural action.

The Satanist/Setian takes a highly relativistic view of the universe, realizing that much of what is conceived as "objective reality" is more accurately understood as part of a prevailing local consensus reality.13
Ultimately it is the Setian who must apply his knowledge. The Prince of Darkness is no redeemer; rather [again after Redbeard - Ed.] every individual Setian must be "his own redeemer".

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant for understanding the philosophical underpinnings and evolution of modern Left-Hand Path traditions, particularly within Setianism. It clarifies the distinctions between LaVeyan Satanism and Setian philosophy, positioning the latter as a complex, dualistic, and existential path of self-divinization. For occult practitioners, it offers a theoretical framework for 'Becoming' (Xeper) as an ongoing, self-directed magical process, emphasizing the non-natural aspect of individual will and psyche-centric reality. It provides a historical and philosophical context for rejecting conventional religious dogma in favor of radical self-empowerment and the creation of personal meaning.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists primarily of serious students, initiates, and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Satanism, Setianism, and the Left-Hand Path. Its academic tone, philosophical depth, and references to internal Temple of Set concepts and authors suggest it is intended for individuals already familiar with basic occult terminology and seeking a deeper, more technical understanding of Setian philosophy, its practical implications, and its intellectual justification against mainstream religious and philosophical views.
